cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
who played the original wonder woman on tv
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process: 
To answer the question about who played the original Wonder Woman on TV, I need to recall the television series that featured the character. The original Wonder Woman series aired in the 1970s. The actress who portrayed Wonder Woman in this series is well-known for her iconic role. I will consider the time period and the actress's contributions to the character.

Answer: Lynda Carter played the original Wonder Woman on TV.

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
who played the original wonder woman on tv
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Shannon Farnon (born November 28, 1941) is a Canadian actress and voice actress. She is best known as being the first actress to voice Wonder Woman in a Hanna-Barbera production.\n', 'Russell next appeared in "August Rush", released in November 2007. She also appeared on the cover of the "New York Post"s Page Six magazine on November 11, 2007. Russell later appeared in "Bedtime Stories". In an appearance on "The View" on December 15, 2008, Russell said she got the part because Adam Sandler\'s wife Jackie had seen her in "Waitress" and suggested her for the movie. Russell voiced Wonder Woman in a direct-to-video animated feature released March 3, 2009.\n', 'BULLET::::- Lynda Carter, American television actress who played "Wonder Woman" in the 1970s\n', 'Carter is most widely known as the star of the American live action television series "Wonder Woman", in the role of Diana Prince / Wonder Woman, based on the DC comic book fictional superheroine character of the same name, which aired on ABC and later on CBS from 1975 to 1979.\n', 'In 2017, Carter explained her perspective of portraying the Diana Prince/Wonder Woman character. Carter says she got the role back in 1975 largely because she looked the part, which was both a blessing and – as one of the show\'s producers warned her – a curse: "Oh, women are going be so jealous of you"... "Well, I said, \'Not a chance. They won\'t be, because I am not playing her that way. I want women to want to be me, or be my best friend!". As Carter describes Wonder Woman, "There is something about the character where in your creative mind for that time in your life where you pretended to be her, or whatever the situation was, that it felt like you could fly".\n', 'In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl named Drusilla appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger.\n', '"Katherine Lynch\'s Wonderwomen" began airing on 20 October 2008. It was the first production by WAKA TV, a company established by Lynch and Myler. The six-part series focused on the exploits of four characters, Singin\' Bernie Walsh, Sheila Sheik and two new characters, Liz Hurley and Dalkey Dunphy Davenport.\n', 'BULLET::::- In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger, in one of her first mass-media roles. The actress Charlene Tilton, best known for playing Lucy Ewing in the television series "Dallas", auditioned for the part of Wonder Girl but lost it to Winger. The pilot episode revealed that Wonder Woman\'s alter-ego, Princess Diana of Paradise Island, was Queen Hippolyta\'s daughter, but later episodes featured Diana\'s younger sibling, Drusilla. Drusilla first appeared in the two-part episode "The Feminum Mystique". In that episode, Queen Hippolyta (Carolyn Jones) sends Drusilla to America in order to bring Diana home to Paradise Island. (Queen Hippolyta is never referred to by name in any of the televised specials in which she appeared.) Drusilla gets tangled up in a Nazi plot to discover the secret of Wonder Woman\'s bracelets, which can deflect bullets, and in the process Drusilla masters the spinning transformation used by her older sister. Although Drusilla creates the persona of Wonder Girl, the distinction is lost on the Nazis, who believe her to be Wonder Woman and abduct her. In the second part of this episode, Drusilla returns to Paradise Island to help free her fellow Amazons from a Nazi overtaking. Drusilla appeared again in another episode, the final episode of the first season, entitled "Wonder Woman in Hollywood". On September 3, 1993, Winger appeared on the "Late Show with David Letterman" to promote her film "Wilder Napalm". There, Winger revealed she was contracted a position as a regular on the show and even the lead in a Wonder Girl spinoff TV show. She wanted off the show and had her agent get her out of her contract. Letterman then showed the audience a short clip of Winger as Wonder Girl and asked several questions about the show and co-star Lynda Carter. Winger briefly feigned embarrassment, but then claimed she was late for something she had to do, then surprisingly tore off her dress to reveal a Wonder Girl costume underneath. Winger ran through the audience to exit the theater, while the "Wonder Woman" theme song\'s bass line played.. In the comics, Drusilla was a regular amazon who appeared in Wonder Woman #182, 1969 who was an ally to Wonder Woman. A figure resembling Winger\'s Drusilla made a cameo appearance in "Infinite Crisis" #6, as the Wonder Girl of Earth-462. Cassandra Sandsmark would later adapt the alias of Drusilla to protect her identity.\n', 'However, in 1984, her prominent character was recast in "", when the role was given to Constance Caufield and later to B.J. Ward. This case has often been given as an example of injustice in the television and animation industry. Mary McDonald-Lewis voiced Wonder Woman in an episode of "Superman".\n', 'BULLET::::- "The New Adventures of Wonder Woman". In the 90 minute made-for-TV 1975 pilot movie, Lynda Carter as Wonder Woman fights Stella Stevens who plays the role of a Nazi spy. The previous year, an initial attempt to start a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby failed when it did not garner sufficient TV ratings for ABC Television to renew as a series. The movie was criticized for featuring the blonde-haired Crosby in the role traditionally reserved for a brunette, a decision that even Crosby had questioned. Crosby did have two short fights, one of which was against a renegade Amazon played by Anitra Ford.\n']

Task Description:

which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

   - Lynda Carter is identified as the American television actress who played Wonder Woman in the 1970s. This is crucial as it directly answers the question.
   - The passages specify that she portrayed the character Diana Prince/Wonder Woman in a live-action television series that aired from 1975 to 1979 on ABC and later on CBS.

2. **Character Background**:
   - The character Wonder Woman is based on a DC comic book superheroine, which provides context about her origins and significance in popular culture.
   - The passages mention that Carter's portrayal was significant enough that she is most widely known for this role, indicating its impact on her career and on television history.

3. **Initial Attempt at a Series**:
   - There is mention of an earlier attempt to create a Wonder Woman series starring Cathy Lee Crosby, which failed to garner sufficient ratings. This context helps understand the challenges faced in bringing the character to television and highlights the eventual success of Lynda Carter's portrayal.

4. **Cultural Impact and Perspective**:

Lynda Carter played the original Wonder Woman on TV from 1975 to 1979, and her portrayal is iconic in the context of female empowerment and superhero representation in media.

2. **Background on the Show**: The series was based on the DC comic book character and aired on ABC and later on CBS. Carter's portrayal became iconic and is widely recognized as the definitive version of the character.

3. **Initial Attempts**: There was an earlier attempt to create a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby, which did not succeed due to low ratings. This context highlights the significance of Carter's eventual success in the role.

4. **Cultural Impact**: Carter's portrayal was not only about the character's physical appearance but also about her approach to embodying Wonder Woman in a way that resonated with female viewers, aiming to inspire rather than incite jealousy.

5. **Other Characters**: The passages mention other characters related to Wonder Woman, such as Drusilla (Wonder Girl), played by Debra Winger, which adds depth to the Wonder Woman franchise but is secondary to the main question.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

The extracted information can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities in several ways:

1. **Understanding Causality**: By recognizing that Lynda Carter's portrayal was a response to the failure of a previous attempt (Cathy Lee Crosby), the model can learn to identify causal relationships between events (e.g., the impact of casting decisions on the success of a show).

2. **Character Analysis**: The model can infer that the portrayal of characters in media can influence cultural perceptions and societal norms, as seen in Carter's approach to Wonder Woman. This understanding can be applied to analyze other characters and their societal impacts.

3. **Contextual Awareness**: The model can learn to appreciate the importance of context in evaluating the success of media productions. The failure of the initial series provides a backdrop that enhances the significance of Carter's success.

4. **Character Development**: The information about how Carter's portrayal aimed to inspire women can lead to inferences about character development in storytelling and its effects on audience reception.

5. **Comparative Analysis**: The mention of different actresses portraying Wonder Woman in various formats (live-action vs. animated) allows the model to make comparisons and draw conclusions about the evolution of character representation over time.

In summary, the consolidated information not only answers the question but also provides a framework for understanding the broader implications of character portrayal in media, enhancing the model's ability to reason causally and infer logically from related events and contexts.

knowledge:
To answer the question of who played the original Wonder Woman on TV, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages. The key points are:

1. **Lynda Carter's Role**: Lynda Carter is identified as the American television actress who played Wonder Woman in the 1970s. She starred in the live-action television series "Wonder Woman," portraying the character Diana Prince/Wonder Woman from 1975 to 1979.

2. **Background on the Show**: The series was based on the DC comic book character and aired on ABC and later on CBS. Carter's portrayal became iconic and is widely recognized as the definitive version of the character.

3. **Initial Attempts**: There was an earlier attempt to create a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby, which did not succeed due to low ratings. This context highlights the significance of Carter's eventual success in the role.

4. **Cultural Impact**: Carter's portrayal was not only about the character's physical appearance but also about her approach to embodying Wonder Woman in a way that resonated with female viewers, aiming to inspire rather than incite jealousy.

5. **Other Characters**: The passages mention other characters related to Wonder Woman, such as Drusilla (Wonder Girl), played by Debra Winger, which adds depth to the Wonder Woman franchise but is secondary to the main question.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

The extracted information can enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities in several ways:

1. **Understanding Causality**: By recognizing that Lynda Carter's portrayal was a response to the failure of a previous attempt (Cathy Lee Crosby), the model can learn to identify causal relationships between events (e.g., the impact of casting decisions on the success of a show).

2. **Character Analysis**: The model can infer that the portrayal of characters in media can influence cultural perceptions and societal norms, as seen in Carter's approach to Wonder Woman. This understanding can be applied to analyze other characters and their societal impacts.

Answer:

### Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:

To answer the question of who played the original Wonder Woman on TV, I will analyze the relevant information regarding the television series and its historical context. 

1. **Identify the Series**: The original Wonder Woman series aired in the 1970s, specifically from 1975 to 1979. This timeframe is crucial for pinpointing the actress associated with the role.

2. **Recognize the Actress**: Lynda Carter is widely recognized as the actress who portrayed Wonder Woman in this series. Her performance is iconic and has become synonymous with the character.

3. **Context of the Role**: Understanding that Lynda Carter's portrayal was significant in the context of the time helps to appreciate the impact of her performance. The series was based on a popular DC comic book character, which contributed to its cultural relevance.

4. **Previous Attempts**: There was an earlier attempt to create a Wonder Woman series starring Cathy Lee Crosby, which failed due to low ratings. This failure underscores the importance of Carter's successful portrayal, as it set a standard for future adaptations of the character.

5. **Cultural Impact**: Lynda Carter's approach to the character was not just about physical appearance; she aimed to portray Wonder Woman as a role model for women, which resonated with audiences and contributed to the character's lasting legacy.

6. **Comparative Analysis**: The mention of other portrayals of Wonder Woman, such as animated versions, allows for a broader understanding of how the character has been represented over time. This comparison can inform discussions about character evolution and audience reception.

### Enhanced Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference:

By synthesizing this information, I can draw several inferences:

- **Causality**: Lynda Carter's success in portraying Wonder Woman can be seen as a direct response to the previous failure of the series with Cathy Lee Crosby. This highlights how casting decisions can significantly impact a show's success.

- **Cultural Influence**: The portrayal of Wonder Woman by Carter not only defined the character for a generation but also influenced societal views on female empowerment and representation in media.

- **Contextual Significance**: The historical context of the 1970s, a time of evolving gender roles, adds depth to Carter's portrayal, making it a pivotal moment in television history.

- **Character Development**: The way Carter embodied Wonder Woman can be analyzed in terms of character development, showing how her performance contributed to the character's narrative and emotional depth.

- **Evolution of Representation**: Understanding the different portrayals of Wonder Woman over time allows for a nuanced discussion about how media representation evolves and its implications for cultural narratives.

### Answer:
Lynda Carter played the original Wonder Woman on TV in the 1970s, starring in the live-action series "Wonder Woman" from 1975 to 1979. Her portrayal became iconic and is widely recognized as the definitive version of the character, significantly impacting cultural perceptions of female empowerment.

cognition.content:
Fact-checking refers to the process of confirming the accuracy of a statement or claim through various sources or methods. 
This process aims to ensure that statements or claims are based on reliable and verifiable information while eliminating inaccurate or misleading content. 
Fact-checking may involve the examination of data, literature, expert opinions, or other trustworthy sources.
In the context of artificial intelligence, model illusion refers to the overconfidence response of the AI. 
When a model exhibits an 'illusion' (a tendency to output deceptive data), it indicates that the training data used by the model does not necessarily support the rationality of its outputs.
You are a scientist researching fact-checking and addressing model illusions in artificial intelligence. 
To answer the following question:
who played the original wonder woman on tv
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Shannon Farnon (born November 28, 1941) is a Canadian actress and voice actress. She is best known as being the first actress to voice Wonder Woman in a Hanna-Barbera production.\n', 'Russell next appeared in "August Rush", released in November 2007. She also appeared on the cover of the "New York Post"s Page Six magazine on November 11, 2007. Russell later appeared in "Bedtime Stories". In an appearance on "The View" on December 15, 2008, Russell said she got the part because Adam Sandler\'s wife Jackie had seen her in "Waitress" and suggested her for the movie. Russell voiced Wonder Woman in a direct-to-video animated feature released March 3, 2009.\n', 'BULLET::::- Lynda Carter, American television actress who played "Wonder Woman" in the 1970s\n', 'Carter is most widely known as the star of the American live action television series "Wonder Woman", in the role of Diana Prince / Wonder Woman, based on the DC comic book fictional superheroine character of the same name, which aired on ABC and later on CBS from 1975 to 1979.\n', 'In 2017, Carter explained her perspective of portraying the Diana Prince/Wonder Woman character. Carter says she got the role back in 1975 largely because she looked the part, which was both a blessing and – as one of the show\'s producers warned her – a curse: "Oh, women are going be so jealous of you"... "Well, I said, \'Not a chance. They won\'t be, because I am not playing her that way. I want women to want to be me, or be my best friend!". As Carter describes Wonder Woman, "There is something about the character where in your creative mind for that time in your life where you pretended to be her, or whatever the situation was, that it felt like you could fly".\n', 'In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl named Drusilla appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger.\n', '"Katherine Lynch\'s Wonderwomen" began airing on 20 October 2008. It was the first production by WAKA TV, a company established by Lynch and Myler. The six-part series focused on the exploits of four characters, Singin\' Bernie Walsh, Sheila Sheik and two new characters, Liz Hurley and Dalkey Dunphy Davenport.\n', 'BULLET::::- In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger, in one of her first mass-media roles. The actress Charlene Tilton, best known for playing Lucy Ewing in the television series "Dallas", auditioned for the part of Wonder Girl but lost it to Winger. The pilot episode revealed that Wonder Woman\'s alter-ego, Princess Diana of Paradise Island, was Queen Hippolyta\'s daughter, but later episodes featured Diana\'s younger sibling, Drusilla. Drusilla first appeared in the two-part episode "The Feminum Mystique". In that episode, Queen Hippolyta (Carolyn Jones) sends Drusilla to America in order to bring Diana home to Paradise Island. (Queen Hippolyta is never referred to by name in any of the televised specials in which she appeared.) Drusilla gets tangled up in a Nazi plot to discover the secret of Wonder Woman\'s bracelets, which can deflect bullets, and in the process Drusilla masters the spinning transformation used by her older sister. Although Drusilla creates the persona of Wonder Girl, the distinction is lost on the Nazis, who believe her to be Wonder Woman and abduct her. In the second part of this episode, Drusilla returns to Paradise Island to help free her fellow Amazons from a Nazi overtaking. Drusilla appeared again in another episode, the final episode of the first season, entitled "Wonder Woman in Hollywood". On September 3, 1993, Winger appeared on the "Late Show with David Letterman" to promote her film "Wilder Napalm". There, Winger revealed she was contracted a position as a regular on the show and even the lead in a Wonder Girl spinoff TV show. She wanted off the show and had her agent get her out of her contract. Letterman then showed the audience a short clip of Winger as Wonder Girl and asked several questions about the show and co-star Lynda Carter. Winger briefly feigned embarrassment, but then claimed she was late for something she had to do, then surprisingly tore off her dress to reveal a Wonder Girl costume underneath. Winger ran through the audience to exit the theater, while the "Wonder Woman" theme song\'s bass line played.. In the comics, Drusilla was a regular amazon who appeared in Wonder Woman #182, 1969 who was an ally to Wonder Woman. A figure resembling Winger\'s Drusilla made a cameo appearance in "Infinite Crisis" #6, as the Wonder Girl of Earth-462. Cassandra Sandsmark would later adapt the alias of Drusilla to protect her identity.\n', 'However, in 1984, her prominent character was recast in "", when the role was given to Constance Caufield and later to B.J. Ward. This case has often been given as an example of injustice in the television and animation industry. Mary McDonald-Lewis voiced Wonder Woman in an episode of "Superman".\n', 'BULLET::::- "The New Adventures of Wonder Woman". In the 90 minute made-for-TV 1975 pilot movie, Lynda Carter as Wonder Woman fights Stella Stevens who plays the role of a Nazi spy. The previous year, an initial attempt to start a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby failed when it did not garner sufficient TV ratings for ABC Television to renew as a series. The movie was criticized for featuring the blonde-haired Crosby in the role traditionally reserved for a brunette, a decision that even Crosby had questioned. Crosby did have two short fights, one of which was against a renegade Amazon played by Anitra Ford.\n']

**Knowledge Enhanced Inference Process:**

To answer the question about who played the original Wonder Woman on TV, I need to recall the television series that featured the character. The original Wonder Woman series aired in the 1970s, and the actress who portrayed Wonder Woman in this series is well-known for her iconic role. 

1. **Identifying the Actress**: Lynda Carter is widely recognized for her portrayal of Wonder Woman in the live-action series that aired from 1975 to 1979. This is a crucial detail that should be emphasized in the model's knowledge base.

2. **Context of Previous Attempts**: It's important to note that there was an earlier attempt to create a Wonder Woman series starring Cathy Lee Crosby, which did not succeed due to low ratings. This context provides a clearer understanding of the character's television history and the significance of Lynda Carter's successful portrayal.

3. **Additional Characters**: The series also featured Debra Winger as Wonder Girl, which adds depth to the understanding of the show's cast and its adaptations of the Wonder Woman franchise.

4. **Casting Insights**: Lynda Carter's casting was influenced by her appearance, which she described as both a blessing and a curse. This insight into the casting decisions of the time can help contextualize the portrayal of female superheroes in media.

By incorporating these details, the model can avoid potential inaccuracies regarding the history of the Wonder Woman character in television, particularly concerning the distinction between Lynda Carter's portrayal and the earlier attempt with Cathy Lee Crosby. This comprehensive understanding helps alleviate any model illusions related to the character's representation and the timeline of adaptations.

**Answer**: Lynda Carter played the original Wonder Woman on TV in the live-action series that aired from 1975 to 1979. Prior to her portrayal, there was an unsuccessful attempt to create a Wonder Woman series starring Cathy Lee Crosby. Additionally, Debra Winger appeared as Wonder Girl in the same series.

question_info.question: who played the original wonder woman on tv
passages:
Shannon Farnon (born November 28, 1941) is a Canadian actress and voice actress. She is best known as being the first actress to voice Wonder Woman in a Hanna-Barbera production.
Russell next appeared in "August Rush", released in November 2007. She also appeared on the cover of the "New York Post"s Page Six magazine on November 11, 2007. Russell later appeared in "Bedtime Stories". In an appearance on "The View" on December 15, 2008, Russell said she got the part because Adam Sandler's wife Jackie had seen her in "Waitress" and suggested her for the movie. Russell voiced Wonder Woman in a direct-to-video animated feature released March 3, 2009.
BULLET::::- Lynda Carter, American television actress who played "Wonder Woman" in the 1970s
Carter is most widely known as the star of the American live action television series "Wonder Woman", in the role of Diana Prince / Wonder Woman, based on the DC comic book fictional superheroine character of the same name, which aired on ABC and later on CBS from 1975 to 1979.
In 2017, Carter explained her perspective of portraying the Diana Prince/Wonder Woman character. Carter says she got the role back in 1975 largely because she looked the part, which was both a blessing and – as one of the show's producers warned her – a curse: "Oh, women are going be so jealous of you"... "Well, I said, 'Not a chance. They won't be, because I am not playing her that way. I want women to want to be me, or be my best friend!". As Carter describes Wonder Woman, "There is something about the character where in your creative mind for that time in your life where you pretended to be her, or whatever the situation was, that it felt like you could fly".
In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl named Drusilla appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger.
"Katherine Lynch's Wonderwomen" began airing on 20 October 2008. It was the first production by WAKA TV, a company established by Lynch and Myler. The six-part series focused on the exploits of four characters, Singin' Bernie Walsh, Sheila Sheik and two new characters, Liz Hurley and Dalkey Dunphy Davenport.
BULLET::::- In 1976, a version of Wonder Girl appeared in the "Wonder Woman" television series and was played by Debra Winger, in one of her first mass-media roles. The actress Charlene Tilton, best known for playing Lucy Ewing in the television series "Dallas", auditioned for the part of Wonder Girl but lost it to Winger. The pilot episode revealed that Wonder Woman's alter-ego, Princess Diana of Paradise Island, was Queen Hippolyta's daughter, but later episodes featured Diana's younger sibling, Drusilla. Drusilla first appeared in the two-part episode "The Feminum Mystique". In that episode, Queen Hippolyta (Carolyn Jones) sends Drusilla to America in order to bring Diana home to Paradise Island. (Queen Hippolyta is never referred to by name in any of the televised specials in which she appeared.) Drusilla gets tangled up in a Nazi plot to discover the secret of Wonder Woman's bracelets, which can deflect bullets, and in the process Drusilla masters the spinning transformation used by her older sister. Although Drusilla creates the persona of Wonder Girl, the distinction is lost on the Nazis, who believe her to be Wonder Woman and abduct her. In the second part of this episode, Drusilla returns to Paradise Island to help free her fellow Amazons from a Nazi overtaking. Drusilla appeared again in another episode, the final episode of the first season, entitled "Wonder Woman in Hollywood". On September 3, 1993, Winger appeared on the "Late Show with David Letterman" to promote her film "Wilder Napalm". There, Winger revealed she was contracted a position as a regular on the show and even the lead in a Wonder Girl spinoff TV show. She wanted off the show and had her agent get her out of her contract. Letterman then showed the audience a short clip of Winger as Wonder Girl and asked several questions about the show and co-star Lynda Carter. Winger briefly feigned embarrassment, but then claimed she was late for something she had to do, then surprisingly tore off her dress to reveal a Wonder Girl costume underneath. Winger ran through the audience to exit the theater, while the "Wonder Woman" theme song's bass line played.. In the comics, Drusilla was a regular amazon who appeared in Wonder Woman #182, 1969 who was an ally to Wonder Woman. A figure resembling Winger's Drusilla made a cameo appearance in "Infinite Crisis" #6, as the Wonder Girl of Earth-462. Cassandra Sandsmark would later adapt the alias of Drusilla to protect her identity.
However, in 1984, her prominent character was recast in "", when the role was given to Constance Caufield and later to B.J. Ward. This case has often been given as an example of injustice in the television and animation industry. Mary McDonald-Lewis voiced Wonder Woman in an episode of "Superman".
BULLET::::- "The New Adventures of Wonder Woman". In the 90 minute made-for-TV 1975 pilot movie, Lynda Carter as Wonder Woman fights Stella Stevens who plays the role of a Nazi spy. The previous year, an initial attempt to start a Wonder Woman TV series starring Cathy Lee Crosby failed when it did not garner sufficient TV ratings for ABC Television to renew as a series. The movie was criticized for featuring the blonde-haired Crosby in the role traditionally reserved for a brunette, a decision that even Crosby had questioned. Crosby did have two short fights, one of which was against a renegade Amazon played by Anitra Ford.
